text: <@U01KXU8UNRX> the reason I was thinking of is that it’s been completely superseded by Git in the world at large, so maintaining a project in Subversion these days seems like a signal (or at least a sign) that outside contributions aren’t welcome or at least aren’t valued.

elements.text: the reason I was thinking of is that it’s been completely superseded by Git in the world at large, so maintaining a project in Subversion these days seems like a signal (or at least a sign) that outside contributions aren’t welcome or at least aren’t valued.

text: I used to use CVS, then transitioned to SVN for all my projects, then transitioned to Git, motivated each time by the desire to collaborate better - and each time I moved I discovered that the tools were *way* better too.  Anyway, I’m sure this has been pointed out a million times to the R core team, I’m probably adding nothing new.

text: I'm relieved there aren't any major problems with svn. Contributions from non R core members are welcomed and valued and there have been several calls for contributions, for example <https://blog.r-project.org/2019/10/09/r-can-use-your-help-reviewing-bug-reports/index.html>. Moving to git(hub) has been brought up yes :smile:

text: Yeah, I’m pretty sure I’ve brought it up myself several times in the past 10 years. :smile:

text:
<@U03FGR4C49G> So I think there are two things at play here which are very much not the same. One is the “demeanor” of CRAN, how they interact with package developers. I don’t think anyone reasonable is going to claim there are not both acute problems and general room for improvement there. That this has lead to a decrease in developer engagement (which I would say may be different from community engagement) is also simply a matter of record at this point (though how much is an open question which anecdotes can’t answer).

The other thing is the requirements themselves.  One can quibble about the value of a couple of the individual checks done, but overall I do absolutely think that those requirements have improved quality of life *for end users* an immense amount, and contributed to the success of R overall. The fact of the matter when R users install an R package from CRAN they can just expect it to work alongside any other packages they got on cran (at the same time) on a very (some argue overly) wide variety of operating systems and architectures.

elements.text:
So I think there are two things at play here which are very much not the same. One is the “demeanor” of CRAN, how they interact with package developers. I don’t think anyone reasonable is going to claim there are not both acute problems and general room for improvement there. That this has lead to a decrease in developer engagement (which I would say may be different from community engagement) is also simply a matter of record at this point (though how much is an open question which anecdotes can’t answer).

The other thing is the requirements themselves.  One can quibble about the value of a couple of the individual checks done, but overall I do absolutely think that those requirements have improved quality of life
for end users

an immense amount, and contributed to the success of R overall. The fact of the matter when R users install an R package from CRAN they can just expect it to work alongside any other packages they got on cran (at the same time) on a very (some argue overly) wide variety of operating systems and architectures.

text: I definitely agree that those are two different issues.  And I agree with your take on the former (obviously), but I disagree on the latter.  For example, I don’t know any comparable C*AN-like archive that actively unregisters packages when some upstream dependency has an issue.  That causes huge problems for end-users.  My take is that by being heavy-handed gatekeepers (something I don’t know a precedent for in other communities) they’ve made the overall user experience quite a bit worse.

elements.text: I definitely agree that those are two different issues.  And I agree with your take on the former (obviously), but I disagree on the latter.  For example, I don’t know any comparable C*AN-like archive that actively unregisters packages when some upstream dependency has an issue.  That causes huge problems for end-users.  My take is that by being heavy-handed gatekeepers (something I don’t know a precedent for in other communities) they’ve made the overall user experience quite a bit worse.

text: Personally I do not think the r community would be well served by the non-malicious-but-otherwise-wild-west cPAN style approach for the simple reason that most R users are not developers. They don’t, on average, have the baseline technical skills that the average CPAN consumer has (they also have other skills the average CPAN consumer is quite unlikely to have)…

I mean maybe, but if the dependancy has been removed, from a practical perspective of actually being able to use the software, it doesn’t exist anymore in CRAN.

There are ways of forcing it to install anyway (I should know, I wrote them) but they are non-trivial and “dangerous” (to the work being done not the computer, and depending on what your goals are)  and should not, I think, be the default behavior
